entry.title: Combined summary - Descriptive annotations visible to intermediate nodes
entry.summary: The Lightning Network is a layer-2 solution built on top of the Bitcoin blockchain that enables faster and cheaper transactions. Transactions made on the Lightning Network travel through various intermediate nodes before reaching their final destination. Annotations are additional information that can be added to a transaction that can provide context and help identify the purpose of a transaction. The addition of annotations to Lightning Network transactions could potentially provide valuable information to users and merchants, but it is important to consider the privacy implications of adding annotations that can be read by all intermediate nodes along a given route.In an email exchange between Benjamin Mord and Christian Decker regarding annotations on a lightning transaction, Benjamin asked if there are or will be annotations that can be added to a Lightning transaction that can be read by all intermediate nodes along a given route or readable only by certain specific known intermediate nodes. Christian suggested that adding information in the onion packet would be possible, wherein specific information can be given to every hop, allowing nodes to add annotations that can be read along the route.In an email to the lightning-dev mailing list, Benjamin asked if there are or will be annotations that can be added to a Lightning transaction that can be read by all intermediate nodes along a given route. ZmnSCPxj responded, suggesting that it may be possible to embed this information in the hash preimage of the receiver. Alternatively, it would be possible to create a new realm to provide such annotations to specific nodes on the route that support that realm, while nodes that do not support this annotation realm would not need to be aware of it.In a mailing list discussion, Christian and ZmnSCPxj are discussing the removal of the payment hash to further decorrelate hops in a payment route. This is being done to make it harder for forwarding nodes to collate hops into a route. However, they point out that there is still the possibility of adding information in the onion packet.Overall, the discussion around the addition of annotations to Lightning Network transactions highlights potential benefits for users and merchants, but also raises important privacy considerations. While there is no standard way to add annotations to a Lightning Network transaction, it is technically possible. It may also be possible to achieve the functionality of adding annotations that are readable only by certain specific known intermediate nodes through custom implementations.
